Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Molecular Beam Epitaxy Chamber for Quantum-Engineered Structures and Devices
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award to the University of Oklahoma is for the acquisition of a state-of-the-art molecular beam epitaxy chamber to accelerate progress in developing a wide range of scientific and technologically important applications for materials containing antimony (Sb). Antimonide materials typically display a relatively narrow band gap, small effective electronic mass, and strong spin-orbit coupling. Interband cascade structures based on the type-II transition between InAs and GaSb quantum wells will be further developed for applications as mid-infrared lasers, photodetectors, and thermophotovoltaic devices. Quantum-dot structures with antimonide compounds as the material for either the dots or the matrix are candidates for solar cells that exploit intermediate band absorption or multi-exciton generation. Exploitation of strong-spin orbit coupling and confinement effects may lead to a new three-dimensional topological insulator in quantum-confined Sb films. Improved InSb quantum-well structures will facilitate further studies of electron spin effects and may enable formation of novel topological superconductor states. The effects of dilute amounts of nitrogen in narrow gap materials will be studied for photovoltaic and photodetector applications.

The molecular beam epitaxy chamber will be used for the training of students in contemporary growth techniques and will create new research opportunities for students studying physics and engineering. Nanotechnology outreach to K-12 students, middle and high school teachers, undergraduates, and senior citizens will be enriched by the enhanced expertise that will result from the acquisition of a new chamber for antimonide growth.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to acquire, commission, and begin using a state-of-the-art chamber for molecular beam epitaxy (MBE). The chamber is accelerating progress in developing a wide range of scientific and technologically important applications by synthesizing multi-layer crystals with precisely controlled layer thicknesses and compositions. The chamber has been used to grow materials in four main research areas. First, interband cascade infrared photodetectors (ICIPs) were fabricated from InAs/GaSb/AlSb materials grown in the MBE system. These structures typically have hundreds of layers made of several compositions of antimonide and arsenide alloys. Operation of the ICIPs was demonstrated at long-wave infrared wavelengths with a working temperature above room temperature. The sensitivity of the detectors at temperatures above 200K was more than a factor of two higher than the corresponding values for existing technology at long wavelengths.

Second, we made progress in optimizing the topological insulator properties of antimony (Sb) quantum wells. We initiated experiments to populate the topological electron states by doping the GaSb barrier material with Te atoms. Electrical measurements confirmed that electrons transfer from the doped barrier to the quantum well. From experiments at high magnetic fields, we determined ways to modify the structure to increase the contribution of the topological insulator states to the electrical conductivity. Third, we worked with an Oklahoma company on developing short-wave infrared detectors using materials grown in the MBE system. By incorporating a buffer layer with a graded composition, we extended the InGaAs alloy compositions used for the absorber layer. The nBn detectors showed improved performance compared to conventional short-wave infrared photodiodes. Fourth, we grew InAs/AlAsSb superlattices to investigate their potential as hot carrier solar cells. Photoluminescence measurements indicated that radiative recombination is inhibited above 90K due to spatial separation of the charge carriers, which arises from the nearly type-II band alignment. The decoupling of phonon-mediated relaxation results in robust hot carriers at higher temperatures, even at lower excitation powers. We are now focused on enhancing hot-carrier effects and integrating the superlattice into solar cell structures.

The chamber has played a key role in meeting the objectives of existing projects and obtaining funding for new projects. Three Ph.D. students (two female, one male) performed dissertation research that required growing materials in the MBE system. The structures from the chamber are used for projects performed by at least seven other graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. Two undergraduates (a Native American and an African American) performed summer research on methods to characterize and clean substrates in vacuum. The MBE system has been the focal point of laboratory tours to high school students, college students, and the general public.
